questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician that his daughter has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode was positive for Benedict's test. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.
 
Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.
 
Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.
 
Reducing substances are seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.
 
Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
 
The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.

Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.solution:
The toxin responsible for the abnormal posturing shown in the image is tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani. It acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release. 

Tetanospasmin, after secretion by the bacterium is cleaved into two peptides linked by a disulphide bond. The larger peptide diffuses to terminals of neurons and migrates by the retrograde axonal transport system to the spinal cord and brainstem. It diffuses to the glycinergic interneurons and GABA secreting neurons there. The smaller peptide degrades synaptobrevin and blocks the release of the inhibitory glycine and GABA. This results in hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis. Even small amounts of the toxin can be lethal.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 4-5 days up to 3 weeks. Muscle spasms usually involve the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

Other options: Proteolysis of target SNARE proteins in the neurons inhibits the release of Ach at the synapse - this is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B IPC. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C)/ Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options - 

Option A - Death by rash or negligent act is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C - Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.  Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS.

Option D -  Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC (Sec.116 BNS). Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow, and his urine appears pale straw. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase.

Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 hours and/or treatment with phototherapy without cessation of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Option A and D: Biliary atresia and Neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option C: Erythroblastosis foetalis has unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: A method involves comparing and quantifying variations in the number of copies of DNA between two samples, namely the test sample and the control sample by generating a visual representation of the specific areas of chromosomes that experience gains or losses. This method is used to detect all the following except?
questions.solution:
The given technique is Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH), it is a technique used to compare and quantify differences in DNA copy numbers between two samples, specifically a test sample and a control sample. It is not used for detecting balanced translocations but is effective in identifying gene amplifications, gene deletions, and copy number variations.

Additionally, it generates a visual representation of the specific areas of chromosomes that experience gains or losses. It is a type of FISH (Fluorescent in-situ hybridisation) and this principle enables the utilisation of the Microarray technique. 

Array-based Comparative Genomic Hybridization (Microarray technique):

In array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labelled with two different fluorescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with the entire human genome.

If the two samples are equal, all spots on the array will fluoresce yellow due to an equal admixture of green and red dyes. In contrast, if the test sample has a deletion or duplication, the probe spots corresponding to it will show skewing toward red or green (depending on gain or loss of material), allowing highly accurate determination of even focal copy number gain or loss anywhere across the genome. The given image shows a Microarray slide.

questions.text: Shown below is a section taken from a specimen of an adrenal gland. Which of the following hormones is secreted by the zone marked as 1 in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the above image, the layer marked as '1' is zona glomerulosa, and aldosterone is exclusively secreted by this layer. 

The adrenal glands are paired retroperitoneal structures present on top of the kidneys. Each adrenal gland consists of an outer cortex, derived from the mesoderm, and an inner medulla derived from the neuroectoderm.  

The adrenal cortex consists of three zones.

  • Zone-1(Outermost), is known as the zona glomerulosa. It consists of whorls of cells that secrete mineralocorticoids like aldosterone and deoxycorticosterone.
  • Zone 2 is known as zona fasciculata, which consists of columns of cells separated by venous sinuses. It primarily secretes glucocorticoids like cortisol(Option B) and corticosterone.
  • Zone 3 is known as the zona reticularis, formed of an interlacing network of cells, which primarily secretes sex steroids like DHEA(Option A) and androstenedione. 

The adrenal medulla, represented by zone 4, is made up of interlacing cords of granulated cells and numerous venous sinuses. It secretes the catecholamines epinephrine, norepinephrine(Option C), and dopamine. These hormones are amines and are derived from tyrosine.

questions.text: Following the excision of the radial head, the patient presented with an inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. Wrist extension was normal, and no sensory impairment was noted. Which of the following is the probable cause?

choices.text: Injury to the radial nerve just below the spiral groove
Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve
Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve
Injury to the common extensor origin

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, there is a likely injury to the posterior interosseous nerve.

It is prone to be injured in radial head fractures as the nerve winds around the radial neck to go into the posterior compartment of the forearm. There is no cutaneous sensory loss in lesions confined to the posterior interosseous nerve.

The radial nerve divides into 2 branches, the superficial (sensory) and the deep (motor) branches at the cubital fossa. 

Deep radial nerve after supplying extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) and supinator, continues as posterior interosseous nerve (PIN). From the posterior compartment, the supinator muscle wraps around the upper 1/3rd of the radius to reach the anterior compartment. 

PIN arches and winds around the radial neck along with the supinator muscle, into the posterior compartment of the forearm. Hence, it is in close relation with the radial head and neck, and the supinator arch or arcade of Froese. 

There is no cutaneous innervation by the posterior interosseous nerve.

questions.text: What is the main action of the muscle marked below?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis and its main action is the elevation of the mandible.

Temporalis muscle originates from the bone of the temporal fossa and the temporal fascia and goes on to attach to the coronoid process and anterior ramus of the mandible. It is innervated by deep temporal nerves which originate from the anterior trunk of the mandibular nerve.

The temporalis muscle elevates the mandible and so closes the mouth. The posterior fibres of the muscle retract the mandible after it has been protruded. These muscle fibers of the temporalis are almost horizontal and are the only source of mandibular retraction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair.  Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of upper eyelid lilac erythema is suggestive of heliotrope rash. This along with the clinical presentation suggestive of proximal myopathy points toward a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis has a predilection for proximal > distal muscle involvement.

Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin

Other options:

Option A: Inclusion body myositis involves both proximal and distal muscles with a predilection for finger/wrist flexors/knee extensors. It is characterized by asymmetric weakness of wrist and finger flexors in arms and quadriceps in legs. Dysphagia is also commonly seen. It is common in adults >50 years of age. Creatinine kinase levels are normal or slightly elevated. Antibodies against 5' nucleotidase are seen in the blood. 

Option C: Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase (CK) and muscle biopsy showing non-specific inflammatory cells in perimysium locations are seen.

Option D: Thickened and indurated skin, called scleroderma, is the distinguishing hallmark of systemic sclerosis. Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of unknown etiology, complex pathogenesis, and variable clinical presentations. The skin manifestation is described salt-and-pepper appearance. Other features include Raynaud's phenomenon, sclerodactyly, vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences, severe flexion contractures, and expressionless facies.

questions.text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months.

The mechanism of contraception are

  • Mainly by preventing ovulation
  • Bringing changes in the cervical mucus
  • Making the endometrium hostile

An important advantage is that it does not affect lactation. Therefore it is an important contraceptive  during the postpartum period to space pregnancies. The side-effects of DMPA include weight gain, irregular menstrual bleeding and prolonged infertility after its use.

questions.text: A bone marrow transplant recipient presents with fever, chest pain, productive cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture of the patient shows the following growth. Which of the following if detected in the serum is the marker for diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The bone marrow transplant recipient with fever, chest pain, productive cough and hemoptysis with sputum culture showing a dark green powdery or velvety growth on sabouraud agar is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis by Aspergillus fumigatus, and serum galactomannan is the marker for diagnosis in this condition.

Galactomannan is a component of the Aspergillus cell wall, and its presence in the serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of the patients is a marker for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. 

Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is a common complication of immunosuppressed individuals like bone marrow transplant recipients where neutropenia is induced. It presents as severe necrotising pneumonia with fever, new onset cough with hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain or pleural rub. Thrombosis and infarction of pulmonary vessels due to the invasiveness of the fungi leads to its systemic spread. 
HRCT shows dense, well-defined lesions with the characteristic halo sign, as shown below.

Sputum culture for the growth of Aspergillus or indirect tests for the detection of galactomannan can be done. The drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis is Voriconazole.

Other options:

Option A- Arabinogalactan is a polysaccharide that is a structural component of mycobacterial cell wall.

Options C and D-  Beta 1-3 glucan and chitin are both components of the fungal cell wall. They are present in other species of fungi as well and are not specific to Aspergillus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with ulcerative colitis presents with 2-3 episodes of bloody stools per day. What should be given to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
5-aminosalicylic acid is effective in inducing and maintaining remission and is considered to be the first-line agent for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, seen in this patient with 2-3 bloody stools per day.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner. The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Ulcerative colitis is graded based on the frequency of bowel movements and systemic involvement. 

  • Mild disease - ≤4 stools per day with/without rectal bleeding.
  • Moderate disease - ≥4 stools per day with few systemic signs of illness.
  • Severe disease - ≥6 blood stools per day with a fever, tachycardia (≥90 beats/min), anaemia (haemoglobin <10.5 g/dL), and elevated levels of inflammatory markers (ESR ≥30 mm/h).
  • Fulminant disease - >10 stools per day with severe anaemia requiring blood transfusion and progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon).

Investigations show elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, faecal calprotectin, and faecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, regenerative mucosal nodules, pseudopolyps, and ulcerations. 

Treatment of ulcerative colitis differs based on the severity of the disease and involves medical and surgical management. Patients with mild to moderate disease are treated with topical or systemic 5-aminosalicylate drugs such as Salazopyrine/Sulfasalazine and Mesalamine (5 ASA) which are first-line therapies. Glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and biologics are effective in patients with moderate to severe disease. 

Azathioprine and cyclosporin are used as steroid-sparing agents. Anti-TNF alpha inhibitors (infliximab, adalimumab) can be used as anti-inflammatories.

Surgery is recommended for patients who do not improve after medical treatment or with toxic megacolon, and perforation.

Other options:

Option A: Budesonide is a synthetic glucocorticoid. It exhibits greater affinity for the glucocorticoid receptor and acts on specific portions of the inflamed gut with minimal side effects. It is effective in treating moderate to severe disease.

Options B & C: Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine are not first-line agents for ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait which is neurotoxic and can cause muscle paralysis. 

Clinical features of bites of Elapidae (cobras, kraits, mambas, coral snakes) present in a similar pattern. The local bite reaction is generally mild with oozing of bloodstained fluid. There is no burning sensation and swelling in the case of Krait bite but present in the case of Cobra bite.

However, their neurotoxic effects are prominent. Systemic symptoms appear after about 30 minutes. The patient feels sleepy, slightly intoxicated, and weakness of legs, and is reluctant to stand or move. Nausea and vomiting are also seen. Cyanosis is very marked.

Paralysis initially presents as ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear within a few minutes after the bite or after some hours. Later, paralysis of the muscles of the face, palate, jaws, tongue, and neck can occur. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of the intercostal muscles and diaphragm. 

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia
  • Hyperacusis
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Gooseflesh
  • Vomiting
  • Hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

questions.text: A young man presented with painful lesions as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome associated with severe pain is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. 

Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. Upon resolution of the acute infection, the virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia. Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually painful and it may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

Other options:

Option B: The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus. 

The below image shows the lesions seen in Molluscum contagiosum

Option C: Herpes simplex virus are classified into two major antigenic types,

  • Type 1 (HSV-1) which is classically associated with facial infections;
  • Type 2(HSV-2) which is typically genital.

Below image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base and is characteristic of Herpes Labialis or Cold sore.

Option D: Chickenpox is caused by a primary infection with the varicella-zoster virus. Most infections occur before the age of 5 but can occur in older children and adults. The lesions develop in 3-5 crops and are polymorphic (present at different stages in each site). In 2–4 days, a dry crust forms leaving a shallow pink depression which, in the absence of secondary infection, heals without scarring. It is non-contagious after the lesions have crusted. They have a typical dewdrop on rose-petal appearance.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on the electron transport chain (ETC) and oxidative phosphorylation. Identify the correct statement about the same.

choices.text: ETC complexes are present in the outer mitochondrial membrane
Complex I of ETC is NADH-Q oxidoreductase
Cyanide and carbon monoxide are inhibitors of complex III
Oxidative phosphorylation of NADH generates 1.5 ATP

Complex I of the electron transport chain is the enzyme NADH-Q oxidoreductase. 

The electron transport chain represents the final pathway through which electrons, originating from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids, are channeled toward a final reaction with oxygen to produce water and ATP. questions.text:
A young teenage boy presents to the emergency department with a history of drug use at a party a couple of hours earlier. He reports symptoms including sweating, headache, anxiety, and hyperactivity. On examination, he has tachycardia and hypertension. Which of the following substances could he have ingested?

LSD-lysergic acid diethylamide
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario provided, the substance the boy may have ingested is likely cocaine.

Cocaine is an alkaloid deliriant extracted from erythroxylum coca.

Acute intoxication with cocaine leads to symptoms spanning 2 stages :

  1. Stage of excitement/euphoria - associated with hypervigilance, anxiety, hyperactivity along with hyper-adrenergic signs of mydriasis, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, hyperthermia, and cardiac arrhythmias. 
  2. Stage of depression - associated with loss of reflexes, muscle paralysis, circulatory and respiratory failure, and coma. 

Chronic intoxication is characterized by toxic delirium and tactile hallucination of bugs (cocaine bugs) or vermin crawling under the skin (formication).

Treatment includes intravenous diazepam for controlling seizures. For ventricular arrhythmias, propranolol may be given intravenously. If the patient has psychosis, haloperidol may be given. Treatment of chronic cocaine abuse requires psychiatric support. 

Other options : 

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C:  Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use. 

Option D:  Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man collapsed suddenly during dinner. He was brought to the emergency room but was declared dead on arrival. Prior to eating, he had been consuming alcohol. No signs of asphyxia were observed, but an autopsy revealed a bolus of food lodged in the larynx. Which of the following statements about this patient's condition is false?

choices.text: Mostly seen in well nourished businessmen
Autopsy often shows food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx
Death is due to mechanical asphyxia causing reflex cardiac inhibition
Death is often prolonged and happens hours later

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most likely suggestive of cafe coronary syndrome. Death in café coronary syndrome occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity. It is sudden and unexpected and happens rapidly.

This is usually seen in well-built businessmen. In this syndrome, the victim dies during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or classical signs of asphyxia.

The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition. The mode of death is cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occurring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

Suppressed gag reflex due to gross intoxication with alcohol or large doses of tranquilizers in mental institutions or hospitals might be the predisposing factors. Autopsy reveals a bolus of food, lodged in the pharynx or larynx.

Death in 'café coronary' syndrome are sudden and unexpected and happen rapidly.

'Café coronary' syndrome:

  • In this syndrome, the victim dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or 'classical signs of asphyxia.
  • Initially thought to be coronary heart disease, autopsy revealed a bolus of food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx.
  • The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.
  • The mode of death is clearly cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occuring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with the diagnosis of mycosis fungoides. Which of the following features is not seen in the histopathological examination in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, civatte bodies are not seen in the histopathological study of mycosis fungoides. They are seen in lichen planus.

Civatte bodies (also known as colloid bodies) are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consisting largely of keratin intermediate filaments and immunoglobulins. 

Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterized by polymorphic patches and plaques with fine scaling usually present on the limbs, breast, and buttocks. The lesions may be pruritic or even asymptomatic.

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane) (Option A).
  • Epidermotropism - pronounced invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis (Option B).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters, forming a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis (Option D).

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with an abnormal gait. On examination, when the patient was asked to stand on the left foot, a right-sided hip drop was observed. Which of the following muscles are paralyzed in this patient?

choices.text: Right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus
Left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus

questions.solution:
The examination of the patient indicates a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait), with sagging on the right side. It is seen in paralysis of the left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles which are supplied by the left superior gluteal nerve. 

The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus: 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

The below GIF shows a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait) with a left superior gluteal nerve injury. 

In the GIF, when the person lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, the right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. The left superior gluteal nerve is injured in this case since it supplies the left gluteus medius and minimus.

Note: These patients can also have a characteristic lurching gait.

questions.text: A 50-year old male, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with dyspnoea, and high output cardiac failure.   Investigations revealed cardiomegaly, and reduced erythrocyte transketolase activity. Which is the vitamin that is deficient?
questions.solution:
The given case history is suggestive of symptoms of wet beriberi and the vitamin-deficient is vitamin B1 (thiamine).

Chronic alcohol consumption is associated with thiamine deficiency due to inadequate dietary intake, malabsorption of thiamine from the gastrointestinal tract, and impaired utilization of thiamine in the cells. Inadequate transketolase activity is suggestive of a deficiency of vitamin B1. 

A deficiency of vitamin B1 causes beriberi. It is of 2 types, Wet Beriberi and Dry Beriberi.

  • Wet Beri beri is associated with CVS manifestation and presents with high-output cardiac failure, dyspnoea, cardiomegaly, and pulmonary oedema.
  • Dry Beriberi: affects both the peripheral and central nervous system. It presents with symmetric motor and sensory neuropathy (pain, paresthesia, loss of reflexes especially in lower limbs). In severe cases, the patient may also present with muscle atrophy.

The provided scenario describes a patient with pO₂ of 85 mmHg, pCO₂ of 50 mmHg, pH of 7.2, and HCO₃⁻ of 36 mmol/L. These findings suggest respiratory acidosis with a compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Step 1: A pH of 7.2 indicates acidosis.

Step 3: The HCO3- levels are increased (>30mmol/L), which is opposite to the change in pH, thus, there is compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Step 4: Even though the compensatory mechanisms try to bring up the pH to the normal level, the pH is still below the normal value, which means that the respiratory acidosis is uncompensated.

Thus, the best option is respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) - It is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY): It is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill-health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state less than full health

questions.text: A patient with cystic fibrosis is started on a medication that facilitates the opening of chloride channels. What is the name of the drug?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the drug used to treat cystic fibrosis by opening chloride channels is ivacaftor.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder in children and adults. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion on chromosome 7q. This encodes CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) protein, which is involved in the regulation of the chloride channel. This mutation results in a lack of Cl− secretion and an increase in ENaC-mediated Na+ and water reabsorption.

The defect in the chloride channel results in the production of hyperviscous, adherent secretions, which can obstruct the airways. This results in a reduced periciliary layer that inhibits the function of the mucociliary escalator and alters the local environment to reduce the effectiveness of antimicrobial secretions. This leads to repeated pulmonary infections, specifically pseudomonas aeruginosa, which can lead to the destruction of lung parenchyma.

Diagnosis is made by elevated sweat chloride levels. Sweat chloride levels are generally elevated > 60 mEq/L. Normally, Cl- is reabsorbed into the sweat glands from sweat. This is inhibited in cystic fibrosis. 

Treatment includes chest physiotherapy, postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators(Option D). Inhaled hypertonic saline helps in mucus clearance. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy can be done in case of pancreatic insufficiency. Drug therapy includes Lumacaftor or Tezacaftor (Option A and C), which help in the correction of misfolded proteins and aid the transport of these proteins to the cell surface. Another drug called Ivacaftor is used, which helps in chloride channel opening.

A lung transplant is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The researcher may use attributable risk to express the increased incidence of asthma in the exposed children.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Other Options:

Option B: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option C: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland are involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation—excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, glucose intolerance, and the diagnosis of an adrenocortical adenoma—is consistent with Cushing syndrome caused by excess production of cortisol. The zona fasciculata layer is primarily involved in this condition as it secretes glucocorticoids like cortisol and corticosterone.

Cushing's syndrome is caused by elevated glucocorticoid (cortisol) production. It can be endogenous (intrinsic hormone production) or exogenous (consumption of excessive glucocorticoids). The endogenous causes can also be classified as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) dependent or independent. 

ACTH is released by the anterior pituitary in response to corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) released by the hypothalamus. It signals the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland to produce more glucocorticoids by a feedback mechanism. In some instances, ectopic production of cortisol is unresponsive to ACTH released by the pituitary gland. Thus, hypercortisolism can be ACTH-dependent or independent. 

  • 60-70% of cases of endogenous hypercortisolism are caused by ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas.
  • 5-10% of ACTH secretion is by ectopic tumors, most commonly being small-cell carcinoma of the lung. 

The most common cause of ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome is primary adrenal neoplasm as seen in this case. 

Clinical features include:

  • Obesity, moon facies, and accumulation of fat in the posterior neck and back (buffalo hump)
  • Decreased muscle mass and proximal limb weakness
  • Hyperglycemia, glucosuria, and polydipsia (secondary diabetes)
  • The skin is thin, fragile, and easily bruised; wound healing is poor, and cutaneous striae are particularly common in the abdominal area.
  • Development of osteoporosis and increased susceptibility to fractures
  • Increased susceptibility to a variety of infections
  • Hypertension
  • Several mental disturbances, including mood swings, depression, and frank psychosis,

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: The arthropod shown in the image is not a vector for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The arthropod shown in the image is a rat flea which is not a vector for Scrub typhus.

Rat fleas are vectors for:

  • Endemic typhus
  • Bubonic plague
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Rat fleas are wingless, their head is conical in shape and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is the propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Endemic typhus is caused by R. typhi. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea faeces are rubbed into the bite wound. Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

Bubonic plague is caused by Yersinia pestis through the bite of infected rat fleas and presents as inguinal buboes. Other types of plague include pneumonic and septicemic plague which are less common than bubonic plague.

Fleas transmit these diseases through the bite of a blocked flea, defecation, or direct mechanical transmission. Control of the disease is done by using insecticides such as 10% DDT, repellents like diethyltoluamide, and rodent control.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mites. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. 

The below image shows the trombiculid mite which is responsible for the transmission of Orientia tsutsugamushi.

  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: Which heart sound occurs immediately after the pressure waveform indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The heart sound occurring just after the pressure waveform marked by the arrow is S1. The waveform marked in the image is 'a wave' and it corresponds to atrial contraction.

S1 (first heart sound) is heard in the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricles contract against closed mitral valves. This occurs after atrial systole, corresponding to an 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure. Thus, S1 can be heard just after the 'a' wave. 

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. 

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

Other options - 

Option A: S4 is heard in the phase of atrial systole where atria contract in the late stage of ventricular filling. This occurs just before S1 and 'a' wave in the JVP. 

Option B: S3 is heard in the passive ventricular filling phase where mitral valves are open. It is seen after the 'v' wave peak in the JVP. 

Option C: S2 is heard due to the closure of aortic and pulmonary valves in the isovolumetric relaxation phase after ventricular systole. It can be heard just before the 'v' wave corresponding to the JVP waveform.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness. There is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The dead body of a child was recovered from a river with froth around his mouth, which reappeared even after wiping it off. Which postmortem finding is not seen in this case?

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.solution:
The above case scenario with frothing is suggestive of antemortem drowning. High concentration of arsenic in the shaft of hair is seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning.

 Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Emphysema aquosum - overinflation of the lungs
    Paltauf’s spots - subpleural hemorrhages that reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.

Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. A peripheral smear showed acanthocytosis. A biopsy specimen of the small intestine is shown below. Identify the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an infant presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis in the peripheral smear, and a histopathological image showing lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein which leads to the inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Thus lipids get accumulate intracellularly. It is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life. They present with failure to thrive and steatorrhea.

Deep tendon reflexes are absent due to peripheral neuropathy and peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis due to lipid membrane defects, which is secondary to marked vitamin E deficiency.

Histopathology shows normal intestinal mucosa except lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed.

Low fat, high caloric, vitamin-enriched diet, and vitamin E in large doses should be given. Inadequate supply of vitamin E results in neurological degeneration and the development of retinitis pigmentosa.

Diarrhea is defined as an increase in stool mass, frequency, or fluidity, typically greater than 200 gm per day. It can be classified into 4 types:

  • Secretory diarrhea is an isotonic stool and persists during fasting.
  • Osmotic diarrhea is due to the osmotic force exerted by unabsorbed luminal solutes. The diarrheal fluid is greater than 50 mOsm. Diarrhea decreases on fasting.
  • Malabsorptive diarrhea is due to failure of nutrient absorption. It is associated with steatorrhea and it gets relived on fasting.
  • Exudative diarrhea is due to inflammatory diseases which has pus and blood on them, it continues during fasting.

Other options:

Option A- Lactase deficiency is due to the absence of lactase in the villous epithelial cells. Lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and exerts an osmotic force causing osmotic diarrhea. Since the defect is biochemical, histology appears normal.

Option C- Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten-containing foods. Histology shows villous atrophy intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia. Plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils are seen in lamina propria.

Histopathology image of celiac disease is shown below:

Option D- Whipple's disease is a malabsorptive syndrome. Histology shows foamy macrophages in the small intestinal propria. The macrophages are laden with gram-positive, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant granules that have partially digested Tropheryma whipplei within the lysosome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with cola-colored urine, oliguria, and facial puffiness for 3 days. On examination, he is found to be hypertensive and his serum C3 levels are low. The urine test is positive for albumin. He had a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. The appropriate step in the management of this patient is _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an 8-year-old boy presenting with cola-coloured urine, oliguria, and facial puffiness for 3 days, along with hypertension, low serum C3 levels, and albumin-positive urine, following a skin infection 4 weeks ago, is indicative of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The appropriate management involves supportive conservative therapy.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It is usually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior. It usually presents with features of the nephritic syndrome including, hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and oedema.

On microscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).
  • Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps.
  • Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane and mesangium.

Management of PSGN is directed at treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension. The majority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservative therapy.

Note:

Although a 10-day course of systemic antibiotic therapy with penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of the nephritogenic organisms, antibiotic therapy does not aﬀect the natural history of acute PSGN. Steroids and cyclosporine are not used in the management of PSGN.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding single exposure point source epidemic ?

choices.text: Has more than one incubation period
Occurs due to prolonged exposure to an agent

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding single exposure point source epidemic is that it is explosive in nature.

Single exposure point source epidemics occur due to a brief and simultaneous exposure to an agent. It has the following characteristics:

  • It has a single peak with no secondary waves.
  • The epidemic tends to be explosive, there is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time.
  • The epidemic curve has a sharp, rapid rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period.

The exposure can be an infectious agent or contaminant in the environment (air, water, food, soil) by industrial chemicals or pollutants. Examples are food poisoning and the Bhopal gas tragedy in India due to methyl isocyanate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the ER due to a suspected stroke. The patient has difficulty forming words but can make noises and give expressions as if he understands the questions asked. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Broca's aphasia.

In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Option C: Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking are impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibres connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

questions.text: Calculate the half-life of a drug 'X' if it has a volume of distribution (Vd) of 50 litres and clearance of 0.1 L/min.
questions.solution:
The half-life of a drug X if it has Vd of 50 litres and clearance of 0.1 L/min is 350 minutes.

In first-order kinetics:

t1/2 - Plasma half-life
Vd - Volume of distribution --> 50.
CL - Clearance --> 0.1

Therefore, 

t1/2 = (0.693≈ 0.7) x 50/0.1 = 0.7 x 500 = 350 minutes.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, and headache for the past 5 days. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the life cycle shown in the image is suggestive of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by leptospira. Humans are infected when the leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or through the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease).

Diagnosis includes:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposit of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.
  • Serotype-specific tests: 
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever.

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that cannot be rubbed off. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an immunocompromised patient presenting with a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that cannot be rubbed off is suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia caused by Epstein Barr Virus (EBV).

Hairy leukoplakia is a distinct oral lesion on the lateral border of the tongue caused by EBV that typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. It appears as white, confluent patches of fluffy or hairy, hyperkeratotic thickenings, almost always on the lateral border of the tongue. Unlike Candida-caused oral thrush, the lesion cannot be rubbed away.

Predisposing factors include Immunodeficiency, haematological malignancies, and steroid abuse.

The Epstein-Barr virus replicates in maturing epithelial cells but not in basal or parabasal keratinocytes. On microscopy, the upper spinous layer shows the characteristic hyperparakeratosis and acanthosis with balloon cells.

Investigations show high levels of EBV DNA in the blood with circulating antibodies against viral capsid antigen (VCA) and early antigen (EA)‐restricted proteins.

Other options:

Option A: Oral Thrush/ oral candidiasis associated with Candida albicans presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off. 

Option B: AIDS-associated Kaposi sarcoma (KS) due to human herpes virus-8 (HHV-8) is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. Kaposi sarcoma mainly affects the hard‐palate mucosa in particular. The gingiva, tongue and buccal mucosa are also involved. The initial lesion is a reddish-purple macule, which develops into a purple nodule swelling that could be widespread and ulcerated.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection is common in and around the mouth. HSV-1 is the primary cause of gingivostomatitis, which is most common in children. The gums are swollen, inflamed and bleed easily. The mucous membranes of the tongue, pharynx, palate, and buccal region are covered in vesicles that appear as white plaques. The plaques turn into ulcers with a pseudomembrane that is yellow in colour. The regional lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

questions.text: A clinical trial is done to compare the safety profile of a certain direct thrombin inhibitor (drug X) with that of heparin in patients undergoing coronary angioplasty. Identify drug X.
questions.solution:
The direct thrombin inhibitor (drug X) used in patients undergoing coronary angioplasty is bivalirudin, which is an alternative to heparin.

Bivalirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) frequently used for anticoagulation in invasive cardiology, particularly percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Unlike other DTIs, it undergoes predominant non-organ elimination (proteolysis) and has the shortest half-life (approximately 25 min).

Heparins and their analogues produce anticoagulant effects indirectly by activating antithrombin-III.

questions.text:
Which of the following are pro-apoptotic factors?
  1. BAK
  2. BAX
  3. BCL2
  4. BCL-XL
  5. MCL1
questions.solution:
BAK and BAX are pro-apoptotic factors, whereas BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1 are anti-apoptotic proteins.

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, occurs due to the activation and release of certain proteases known as caspases. These enzymes are regulated by a balance between the actions of pro- apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins on the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane:

  • Pro-apoptotic proteins increase membrane permeability, thereby causing leakage of proteins that initiate apoptosis, like cytochrome c.
  • Anti-apoptotic proteins keep the membrane impermeable, preventing the release of cytochrome c.

There are two apoptotic pathways-

  • The intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway
  • Extrinsic or death-receptor initiated pathway

The intrinsic pathway is triggered by DNA damage, accumulation of misfolded proteins, and loss of survival signals. This leads to leakage of pro-apoptotic proteins like cytochrome c into the cytoplasm. Cytochrome c binds to APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming an apoptosome. This complex activates caspase 9. 

The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the engagement of death receptors on the plasma membrane. It activates caspases 8 and 10. 

The active forms of these caspases activate executioner caspases (3 and 6), which act on various cell components to cause nuclear fragmentation, DNA degradation, etc. Cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies are then formed, which are ultimately phagocytosed.

questions.text: Condition favourable for adipocere formation is _________

choices.text: Hot weather and dry air currents

questions.solution:
Warm and humid weather is a favourable condition for adipocere formation.

Adipocere formation, also called corpse wax, grave wax, or mortuary wax, is a late sign of death. A wax-like organic substance is formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fat in tissues. It has a greyish-white appearance with a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months, but in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 3 to 15 days after death. 

Prerequisites for adipocere formation:

  • Abundant fat
  • Moisture
  • Still air
  • Warm temperature
  • Bacteria producing fat splitting enzyme like Clostridium welchii

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death that is observed in the first 12 to 24 hours of death):
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

questions.text:
Which of the following is not associated with CRISPR-Cas9?

CRISPR- Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 is not associated with post-translational modification.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9 or CRISPR-Cas9 is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components, Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single guide RNA or sgRNA responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a tool for modifying gene expression using the above-mentioned mechanism. It can be used to introduce breaks and repair DNA by non-homologous end joining (Option B). After creating the same breaks, an RNA with a complementary base can be added to silence the expression and knockout (Option D) the desired gene.

FELUDA (Option C) is a CRISPR-Cas9 based test to detect the genomic sequence of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and is used as a quicker, cheaper and effective alternative to RT-PCR.

Many proteins are synthesized as precursor pro-proteins that require modifications before attaining biological activity. Many of the post-translational modifications involve the removal of amino-terminal amino acid residues by specific aminopeptidases and the addition of hydroxyl and other groups by specific enzymes. CRISPR is used for modification at the transcriptional or translational level and is not a tool for post-translational modification.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the anomaly shown below?

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistance of prechordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.solution:
The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which occurs due to the persistence of pluripotent cells of the primitive streak in the sacrococcygeal region. The prechordal plate simply refers to the cells that have invaginated in the cranial region.

Sacrococcygeal teratomas occur due to remnants of pluripotent cells from the primitive streak due to defective migration of the cells (Option B). As these cells are from the epiblast, teratomas contain tissues from all germ layers which may include skin, hair, cartilage and bone (Option C). These tumors are benign (Option D), but may rarely become malignant. If they occur in the cranial end of the primitive streak, they form oro-pharyngeal teratomas (as shown below), whereas if they occur in the caudal end of the primitive streak in the coccygeal region, they are called sacrococcygeal teratomas.

During the third week of embryological development, the process of gastrulation occurs, which refers to the formation of the three germ layers. These germ layers are formed from the primordial germ cells of the epiblast, which are pluripotent. The process begins with the formation of the primitive streak on the epiblast, which develops into the primitive node in the cranial region, and a primitive pit. The cells from the epiblast, migrate towards the primitive streak and invaginate into the primitive pit and organizes themselves into cells arranged in three layers, which eventually develop into ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The prechordal plate simply refers to the cells that have invaginated in the cranial region.

questions.text: The reaction below summarises the formation of an end product of arginine. Identify the enzyme X.
questions.solution:
The enzyme X is nitric oxide synthase (NO synthase). Nitric oxide is synthesised from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalysed by NO synthase. 

Arginine, O2, and NADPH are substrates for cytosolic NO synthase. The co-enzymes of NO synthase include flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

There are three types of NO synthases. Two are Ca2+-calmodulin-dependent enzymes found in vascular endothelium and neural tissue, and one is a Ca2+-independent enzyme that is expressed in cells such as hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, and activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby decreases smooth muscle contraction.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and γ-interferon released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitters in the brain

Other options:

Option B: Arginase catalyzes the cleavage of L-arginine, forming urea and L-ornithine. Defective arginase leads to the inherited metabolic defect hyperargininemia.

Option C: Arginine-glycine amidinotransferase acts on glycine and arginine producing guanidinoacetate, which is a step in the biosynthesis of creatine and creatinine.

Option D: Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from Carbamoyl Phosphate in the urea cycle.

The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. 

The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibres of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) then emerges from the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through Dorello's canal. questions.text: Brown sequard syndrome is characterized by ________

choices.text: Contralateral  loss of pain and temperature sensation
Contralateral weakness and spasticity of muscle groups
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
Brown sequard syndrome is characterised by contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumour. The clinical features are:

  • Damage to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus results in the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception on the same side of the body below the level of the affected area.
  • When the spinothalamic tract is affected, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body, starting one or two segments below the lesion.
  • Injury to the corticospinal tract leads to weakness and spasticity in specific muscle groups on the affected side of the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a sarcomere and the arrow points towards the Z-line and its constituent is alpha-actinin. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

Sarcomere is the area between two dark Z-lines. It is composed of thick filaments like myosin and thin filaments like actin, tropomyosin, and troponin. 

The difference in the refractive index of various muscle fibres leads to cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. The various levels of a section of the sarcomere and the myofilaments they are composed of are as follows.

A band (excluding H zone) Actin and myosin

  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: The patient exhibited an unsteady "drunk like" gait and the physician noted that he swayed while entering the examination room. Which region of the cerebellum was most likely affected by the bleed?
