questions.text: A corpse is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death in a case where the ligature is completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid, with no saliva dribbling, is ligature strangulation.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

Option C: Gagging is a type of asphyxia due to forcible closure of the mouth by a cloth or closing the mouth and nose and is tied around the head. 

Option D: Hanging is characterized by an incomplete and oblique ligature mark on the neck. It is usually seen higher, between the chin and larynx. Saliva often dribbles from the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids plays a key role in the generation and transmission of visual impulses in the retina?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is responsible for signal transmission as well as the generation of impulses in the retina. 

Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

Visual pigments are a type of G-protein-coupled receptors. The receptor protein, known as opsin, is locked in its inactive state by 11-cis retinal. Isomerization and photo-excitation result in the activation of G-protein and the production of cyclic GMP. Transducin serves as the G-protein specifically within the retina. The nerve impulse that is produced in the retina is then conveyed to the visual centres in the brain. The signal is ended through the process of phosphorylation, specifically targeting a serine residue on the activated rhodopsin. This phosphorylation is carried out by an enzyme called rhodopsin kinase. The purpose of this phosphorylation is to allow the inhibitory protein beta-arrestin to connect to the rhodopsin and deactivate it.

The phos­phorylation of membrane-bound phosphatidylinositol (PI) produces polyphosphoinositides such as phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).

The degradation of PIP2 by phospholipase C occurs in response to the binding of a variety of neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors to receptors on the cell membrane. The degrada­tion products are :

  • Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) which mediates the mobilization of intracellular calcium
  • Diacylglycerol (DAG) which activates protein kinase C

Both of these act synergistically to evoke specific cellular responses thus accomplishing signal transmission.

Other options:

Option A: Phosphatidylserine, a phospholipid, is a component of the cell membrane. It is composed of serine and phosphatidic acid. It plays a key role in cell cycle signalling, coagulation and apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Phosphatidylcholine is a major phospholipid in cell membranes, essential for maintaining structural integrity and signalling. It also plays a key role in lipid metabolism and is a precursor for acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter.

Option D: Phosphatidylethanolamine is a major phospholipid found in cell membranes, crucial for membrane stability and fusion. It also plays a role in lipid metabolism and supports cellular processes like autophagy.

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with right hypochondriac pain and yellowish discoloration of eyes. His ultrasound is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the causative agent of his condition?

choices.text: Sheep is the ideal definitive host
The larval stage is found in dogs
Mode of infection is by skin penetration

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG showing a cyst with detached membranes (water lily sign) are suggestive of a hydatid cyst. Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Humans are accidental hosts in their life cycle.

The life cycle of Echinococcus consists of dog (optimal host) and wolf as the definitive hosts, sheep (Option A) and cattle as intermediate hosts. Sheep is the ideal intermediate host because transmission occurs when hydatid cysts from sheep carcasses are eaten by dogs in slaughterhouses. The mode of infection is by the feco-oral route. Humans get infected (Option D) following the ingestion of food items contaminated with dog faeces containing the eggs of Echinococcus. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

The larval stage(Option B) of the parasite is passed in intermediate hosts, including man, giving rise to a hydatid cyst, which usually develops three weeks after the infection.

The life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus is as shown in the image below:

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

questions.text: Observe the following curves, which of the following is true statement about sensitivity and specificity when the curve changes from green to pink?
questions.solution:
The true statement is both sensitivity and specificity increase.

Sensitivity: Proportion of all people with disease who test positive, or the probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate

Specificity: Proportion of all people without disease who test negative, or the probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.
Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 – false-positive rate

In this question, switching from green to pink increases number of true positive and true negatives and decreases false positive and negatives.
Hence leading to increased sensitivity and specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking.  On examination, microcephaly and marked regression of language milestones were noticed. What is the pattern of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly. It has an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance.

It is mainly caused by gene mutation of methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) and the condition is predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as hand wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

questions.text:
The SpO2 values of 5 patients in an ICU ward are given below. Which of the following statements is true?
SpO2 levels 90% 92% 92% 92% 94%
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, mean = median = mode.

The mean is the sum of all the elements divided by the number of elements in the distribution. In this scenario, the mean = (90 + 92 + 92 + 92 + 94) / 5 = 460/ 5= 92%

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. In this scenario, the median = 92% which is the middle value.

The mode is the observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency. In this scenario, the mode = 92%

Hence, the mean = median = mode = 92%

In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same,  mean = median = mode. In a positively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the positive direction, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode. In a negatively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the negative direction, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Other options:

Option D: There is only one value that occurs with the greatest frequency. Hence, the frequency distribution is unimodal. If two values occur with the greatest frequency then the frequency distribution is bimodal. If more than two values occur with the greatest frequency then the distribution is multimodal.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

questions.text: A study was conducted among the postgraduate students in a medical college to find out the time taken by them to complete various tasks in different clinical departments. Which management technique is being applied for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The management technique that is being applied for the above study is work sampling.

Work sampling is a quantitative management technique. It refers to the systematic observation and recording of the activities of one or more individuals. It is done at predetermined or random intervals. It mainly includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to perform the same.

These studies have been done on doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians. This technique can find the appropriateness of the current staff, job description, and training. This may standardize the methods of performing activities and determine the manpower needed in an organization.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

Management techniques are of two types:

Quantitative methods

Methods based on behavioral sciences
  • Cost-Benefit analysis
  • Cost-Effective analysis
  • Cost-Accounting
  • Input-Output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis
    • Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    • Critical Path Method (CPM)
  • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making
  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Other options:

Option A: Cost-effective analysis is a management technique in which the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in terms of the results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Option C: Critical pathway method is a type of network analysis technique. The longest path in the network is called the critical path. If any delay in activity along the critical pathway, the entire study will be delayed.

Option D: Input-output analysis is an economic technique to analyze the amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time). Output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the information obtained from the vaccine vial monitor 14 (VVM14) shown in the image below.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the inner square and outer circle reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the outer circle color  becomes darker

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cellular receptor for the RNA virus shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a bullet-shaped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA is characteristic of rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae. The cellular receptor for the rabies virus is the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.

Other options:

Option A: CR2 or CD21 is the receptor for the C3d component of complement. It also acts as the viral receptor for Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Option A: CD4 is expressed on macrophages and T lymphocytes are the viral receptor for HIV. Chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR5 act as coreceptors.

Option A: SARS-CoV-2 enters the host cell via the ACE2 receptor.

questions.text: You are conducting a survey to investigate the prevalence of hypertension in a community. The data collected from individuals shows an association between obesity, decreased physical activity, and hypertension. Which of the following best describes this type of study?
questions.solution:
The study design shown here to investigate the prevalence of hypertension and its associations in a community at one point in time best describes a cross-sectional study.

A cross-sectional study is the simplest observational study which involves the examination of a population at a particular point in time. It can be used to determine the prevalence of a disease and the prevalence of associated variables of interest. Thus, it is also known as a "prevalence study."

Cross-sectional studies are particularly useful in determining the prevalence of chronic diseases like hypertension. It helps us determine associations (eg. obesity and decreased physical activity in this case) and for planning how to address the prevention of the disease. However, we cannot determine causality from a cross-sectional study. Observational studies only help us determine associations which can then be tested for causality by analytical studies.

Other options:

Option A: An ecological study assesses an entire population as a whole. The study is done at the population level using population-based data. The study described here uses data at an individual level.

Option B: Case series is a compilation of similar cases of a particular disease. It is mostly used in hospital-based studies or healthcare surveys. 

Option D: A cohort study, which can be either prospective or retrospective, is done for a group of individuals who have been or haven't been exposed to a particular risk factor. It is done over a period of time to determine causality. It also tells us about the incidence of diseases. 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A child with a history of intubation presented to the OPD with shortness of breath while playing, approximately six weeks later. X-ray finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this child with a history of intubation and shortness of breath with X-ray showing the 'steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing is acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months to 6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization rapidly improves upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway oedema.
  • Dexamethasone is administered by the least invasive route (Oral > IV > IM ) for all grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %).

Antibiotics are not indicated in acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency presenting in children with a rapidly progressive course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and respiratory obstruction, followed by a toxic appearance and drooling. The neck is hyperextended and stridor is a late finding. Radiography shows a classic thumb sign as given in the image below.

Option C: In children with acute bronchitis, chest radiographs typically show minimal to non-specific findings. The most common radiological features include hyperinflation of lung fields, indicating air trapping and bronchial wall thickening.

Option D: Laryngomalacia is a congenital laryngeal anomaly presenting in children with low-pitched inspiratory stridor exacerbated by exertion. The laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is given below.

questions.text: The carnitine shuttle is essential for the transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following biochemical findings do you expect to find in a patient with carnitine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Carnitine deficiency is characterized by hypoketotic hypoglycemia with associated hyperammonemia. Hence, a patient with this disorder will have ↓ blood glucose and ↓ blood ketones (option D). 

The carnitine shuttle plays a very important role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) across the mitochondrial membrane for the beta-oxidation of the LCFAs. LCFAs are converted in the cytosol to long-chain fatty acyl-CoAs. These compounds diffuse through the outer mitochondrial membrane where they are converted to acylcarnitine by the enzyme carnitine palmitoyltransferase-1. The acylcarnitine so formed can penetrate the inner mitochondrial membrane. This is how fatty acids reach the mitochondrial matrix. The acyl group is transferred back to CoA, restoring acyl-CoA and liberating carnitine, which is moved back to the intermembrane space.

Carnitine deficiency results in impaired transport of LCFAs into mitochondria and impaired beta-oxidation, in the face of depletion of glucose stores in the body. This results in reduced energy production from fatty acids and reduced ketone formation, resulting in the characteristic hypoketotic hypoglycemia.The associated hyperammonemia results from the decreased expression of enzymes in the urea cycle.

The role of carnitine in the metabolism of fatty acids is demonstrated in the image below:

Clinical features of carnitine deficiency begin in childhood and include poor feeding, lethargy, liver dysfunction and hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and dilated cardiomyopathy. Treatment involves oral supplementation of carnitine.

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with XDR-TB is started on a newer anti-TB drug that inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis under aerobic conditions. Identify the likely drug.

XDR - extensively drug-resistant
TB - tuberculosis
questions.solution:
A newer anti-TB drug that inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis under aerobic conditions is pretomanid. 

Pretomanid is a bicyclic nitroimidazole that has been approved for the management of XDR TB. The drug has two mechanisms of action. Under aerobic conditions, it inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis. Additionally, in non-replicating bacteria, pretomanid generates reactive nitrogen species to aid in the killing of intracellular, persistent bacilli. 

Pretomanid is administered at a dose of 200 mg once daily and is used in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid for the management of MDR and XDR TB.
 
Other options:
 
Option A: Bedaquiline is another newer anti-TB drug that acts by blocking mycobacterial ATP synthase. It inhibits bacillary energy metabolism and is used in the management of MDR and XDR TB.
 
Option B: Delamanid is also a newer bicyclic nitroimidazole like pretomanid. However, it acts by only inhibiting bacterial mycolic acid production. It is used in the management of MDR TB.
 
Option C: Ethionamide is an older anti-TB drug. It also acts by inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis. It is a second-line drug that can be used for some cases of drug-resistant TB.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors help to signal the degree of joint rotation?
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor found in joint capsules and helps signal the degree of joint rotation are Ruffini's end organ.

Ruffini's end organ is located in the deep layers of skin and other internal tissues. This is a type of slow-adapting receptor. They play a crucial role in signalling states where tissue deformation is continuous. These include deep touch which is prolonged and pressure signals.

They are located in joint capsules as well and help in signalling the degree of joint rotation.

Other options:

Option A: Merkel discs are a type of expanded tip tactile receptors that cause the epithelium of the skin to bulge out creating a dome and are highly sensitive. They are hence grouped with touch domes. Aβ myelinated sensory nerves carry the receptor signals and are slow to adapt. They play an important role in point discrimination, point localization, and determination of texture along with Meissner's corpuscles.

Option B: Meissner’s Corpuscles are encapsulated receptors found in the dermis of the non-hairy skin, most commonly on the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is very good. Their field of reception is very small and hence used for two-point discrimination. These are rapidly adapting receptors that encode, point discrimination, precise location, tapping and flutter.

Option C: Pacinian corpuscle: They are found both beneath the skin and in deep fascial planes. Only rapid local compressions stimulate these receptors as they adapt very rapidly. They are hence immensely important in the vibration sense and other rapid mechanical changes of tissues.

questions.text: Which drug is used to treat multiple myeloma that is known to cause reactivation of Herpes zoster?
questions.solution:
The drug used to treat multiple myeloma and that has the potential to cause reactivation of herpes zoster is bortezomib.

Bortezomib is an inhibitor of proteasome-mediated protein degradation. It is central to the treatment of multiple myeloma, both untreated and relapsed. Bortezomib is given intravenously or subcutaneously and dosage depends upon the disease, route of administration, and the patient’s history.  It is known to predispose patients to the reactivation of herpesvirus, including Herpes Zoster.

Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, neutropenia, anaemia, anorexia, nausea, limb pain, dizziness, etc. Other adverse events like cardiac tamponade, disseminated intravascular coagulation, toxic epidermal necrolysis, etc. have been reported. 

Other options:

Option B: Lenalidomide is the drug of choice in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) associated with 5q deletion, and is an immunomodulatory analogue of thalidomide. It suppresses bone marrow and is often associated with significant leukopenia.

Option C: Daratumumab is a monoclonal antibody against CD-38. 

Option D: Elotuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against SLAMF7, a glycoprotein expressed in multiple myeloma cells and natural killer cells. It is used in combination with lenalidomide and dexamethasone for the treatment of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Which of the following gene defects is responsible for the condition depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a rash around the perioral area and groin, extending to the inguinal folds and genitals, along with alopecia. This presentation is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is caused by a defect in the SLC39A4 gene.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene (SLC39A4)on chromosome 8q. 

The SLC39A4 gene encodes a transmembrane protein that is part of the zinc/ iron-regulated transporter-like protein(ZIP) family required for zinc uptake. This protein is expressed in the enterocytes in the duodenum and jejunum and the patient will have a decreased ability to absorb zinc from dietary sources.

Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhoea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial (perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease associated with mutations in a member of the ATP-binding cassette transporter family of proteins (ABCD1), which is involved in the transport of molecules into the peroxisome. In the typical form of the disease, young males present with behavioural changes and adrenal insufficiency.

Option C: Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an abnormal ATP7B gene in chromosome 13 which is characterised by liver disease, degenerative changes in the brain, and Kayser-Fleischer (K-F) rings in the cornea.

The image of the KF ring is given below.

Option D: Menkes disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. It is caused by a defect in the ATP7A gene that codes for a copper-transporting protein. There is a defect in intestinal copper absorption and transport resulting in low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels.

Symptoms begin in infancy and are characterized by developmental delay, failure to thrive, hypotonia, hypothermia, and seizures. Facial features include chubby cheeks with associated colourless, friable hair as given in the image below.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with complaints of delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability. On examination, the child had coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea. Which of the following recombinant enzymes is useful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with intellectual disability, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea is suggestive of Hunter's disease. Idursulfase a.k.a Elaprase is used in the treatment of this condition.

Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II (MPS II) resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

All MPS are inherited in an AR manner, except Hunter’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The clinical features include coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike other mucopolysaccharidosis, these patients lack clouding of the cornea.  

Elaprase a.k.a Idursulfase (Recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice for Hunter's disease to ameliorate nonneural manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C: Galsulfase a.k.a Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, marked corneal clouding, and contractures. 

Option D: Myozyme a.k.a Alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding.

questions.text: The gross appearance of the liver observed during the autopsy of a chronic alcoholic, as depicted in the image, is due to the activation of which type of cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cells. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin but in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The sinusoidal endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma who underwent chemotherapy presents with hair loss after 3 weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Anagen effluvium arises from the disruption of the anagen phase of the hair cycle, primarily occurring after chemotherapy. 

It is due to the disruption of the anagen or proliferating phase of the hair cycle. Hair shedding typically occurs within 1–3 weeks and it is complete within 1–2 months after the initiation of chemotherapy.

The most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  • Anti-microtubule agents (e.g., paclitaxel)
  • Topo-isomerase inhibitors (e.g., doxorubicin)
  • Alkylating agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide)
  • Anti-metabolites (e.g., 5-Fluorouracil)

The image below depicts the pattern of hair loss seen in anagen effluvium.

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata causes patchy, well-circumscribed hair loss, as shown below.

Option B: Telogen effluvium is a type of nonscarring alopecia that is marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle.  It can be either acute or chronic.

Option D: Trichotillomania (trichotillosis) is considered an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) spectrum disorder, marked by gratification from pulling one's own hair. Scalp histology will show perifollicular haemorrhages and intrafollicular pigment casts.

questions.text: A patient took medication for migraine relief and subsequently experienced numbness, with their hand appearing as shown below. What is the likely drug involved?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient took medication for migraine relief and later developed numbness along with bluish discolouration of the fingers, as seen in the image. The most likely drug involved is dihydroergotamine.

Dihydroergotamine, used for migraines, can cause peripheral blood vessel occlusion in susceptible individuals. The numbness progressing to bluish discolouration of the fingers is the initial sign of occlusion. It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine include peripheral vascular disease, coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, fever and/or sepsis, pregnancy and within 24 hours of using triptans

Migraine is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches often associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, vertigo, and loose motions. Migraines can be divided into migraine with aura (classical migraine) in which the headache is preceded by visual or other neurological symptoms, and migraine without aura.

questions.text: What is culture contact also known as?
questions.solution:
Culture contact is also known as acculturation.

Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people. This can happen in the following ways:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Religious propagation
  • Education
  • Conquest

Acculturation can influence people in both good and bad ways. Widespread use of tobacco is a bad example of acculturation. However, the introduction of scientific medicine is a good example of acculturation.

Other options -

Options A and C - Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by society.

Option D - Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

Note: Socialization is defined as a process by which man acquires beliefs, customs, traditions, and prejudices of society due to his everyday interaction with people of the society.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation and salivation. Pulse rate i s 110/min. The plasma cholinesterase level is 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient admitted to the emergency department with diarrhoea, sweating, excessive lacrimation and salivation with PR-110/min and plasma cholinesterase level of 50U/mL is suggestive of organophosphate poisoning and the treatment of choice is IV atropine.

The organophosphates(OP) that are commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity, which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes, diarrhoea, urination, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, emesis, lacrimation, salivation, and sweating. (Mneumonic-DUMBBELSS).

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Treatment of OP poisoning includes:

  • Maintenance of vital signs particularly respiration.
  • Removal of clothing and washing of the skin.
  • IV atropine 2- 5 mg, if IV administration is not possible, then 2 mg IM  every 5-10 minutes (till muscarinic symptoms disappear).
  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypercholesterolemia, prompting the clinician to review the biochemistry of cholesterol synthesis. Which of the following compounds serves as the primary precursor for cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver, adrenal cortex, testes, ovaries, and intestine.

The enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis are partly located in the endoplasmic reticulum and partly in the cytoplasm. The enzyme HMG-CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

Cholesterol regulates the expression of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When cholesterol is less, proteases in the golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG-CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG-CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG-CoA reductase

questions.text: Which of the following diseases shows the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis shows the iceberg phenomenon.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon refers to the concept that only a fraction of cases of a disease are visible or reported, with a larger "hidden" burden below the surface. Once a patient is diagnosed and treated, the impact of underdiagnosis or hidden cases on individual treatment outcomes is minimal. Treatment effectiveness depends more on factors such as drug efficacy, patient adherence, and healthcare delivery rather than the overall prevalence of the disease in the population.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: A 14-day-old baby is being evaluated in the pediatric department for ambiguous genitalia. On examination, the baby is dehydrated. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Karyotyping evaluation demonstrates 46, XX chromosomal pattern. Measurement of which of the following will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates congenital adrenal hyperplasia (classical 21-hydroxylase deficiency), and the diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia(CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Children usually present with salt-wasting crises as seconded by dehydration with hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

The diagnosis is confirmed by markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. The most commonly performed neonatal screening programs screen only for 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in dried blood obtained by heel stick and absorbed on filter paper cards. Also, these same cards are screened in parallel for other congenital conditions, such as hypothyroidism and phenylketonuria.

Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment. Patients with salt-wasting and virilizing forms are treated with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone. Surgical treatment is usually done between 2-6 months of age for significantly virilized females.

Males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency who have had inadequate corticosteroid therapy may develop testicular adrenal rest tumours. These usually regress following increased steroid dosage.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with epilepsy was started on an anti-epileptic medication and subsequently developed the side effect shown in the image. What is the possible mechanism of action of the drug he is taking?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gum hypertrophy, which is commonly seen with phenytoin. The mechanism of action of phenytoin is the prolongation of Na+ ion channel inactivation. It slows down the rate of recovery of Na+ channels, thus limiting the propagation of the action potential.

Phenytoin also inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby decreasing calcium influx into the cell membrane. It also reduces the inward flow of potassium ions during repolarization. At higher or toxic doses, phenytoin enhances GABAergic activity and suppresses glutamate action.

Despite its narrow therapeutic index, phenytoin is used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, complex partial seizures, status epilepticus, trigeminal neuralgia, and behavioural disorders.

It is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by craniofacial anomalies like hypertelorism and epicanthal folds, short nose and deep nasal bridge, malformed and low set ears, short neck, hypoplastic distal phalanges and underdevelopment of nails of fingers and toes, growth retardation, cognitive deficits and motor developmental delay. 

Other side effects of phenytoin include behavioural changes, increased frequency of seizures, gingival hyperplasia, megaloblastic anaemia, osteomalacia, hirsutism and hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A diabetic patient came with the complaint of pedal edema due to congestive heart failure and was prescribed a medication that is preferred in the setting of cardiac and renal failure. What is the drug?
questions.solution:
In this case, a diabetic patient with cardiac and renal failure is started on a suitable medication. The drug is likely an sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor.

SGLT-2 inhibitors include canafliflozen,dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild weight loss and reduction in blood pressure. Drugs like empagliflozin and canagliflozin are found to reduce major cardiovascular events. SGLT2 inhibitors also exhibit a known nephro-protective effect.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D.

Other options :

Option A:  Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It reduces the intestinal absorption of glucose by inhibiting the intestinal brush border enzyme, alpha-glucosidase. These drugs also increase GLP-1 levels in circulation. They reduce post-prandial glucose levels.

Option C: Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure. Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors enhance the release of insulin postprandially, decrease glucagon, and thereby lower mealtime as well as fasting glucose. They are weight-neutral.

Option D: Liraglutide is also a GLP-1 receptor agonist and is given only in the subcutaneous injectable form. It was recently approved for the treatment of obesity.

questions.text: The overdrive mechanism observed during hyperventilation is due to_____

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons (DRG) in the medulla
Ventral group of neurons (VRG) in the medulla

questions.solution:
The ventral respiratory group contributes to the extra respiratory drive (overdrive mechanism).

Respiratory neurons called dorsal respiratory group (DRG) and ventral respiratory group (VRG) in the dorsal and ventrolateral portions of the medulla respectively have projections on the pre-BÖTC pacemaker neurons.

During inspiration, DRG (Option B) generates respiratory rhythm by initiating inspiratory ramp signals. DRG is regulated by pneumotaxic (Option A) and apneustic centres (Option C). The apneustic centre prolongs the duration of inspiration. The centre switches off the ramp signal, thus controlling the respiratory rate.

When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, for example, during exercise, respiratory signals spill over to VRG from DRG. So, VRG contributes to the extra respiratory drive (overdrive mechanism).

During quiet breathing, expiration is a passive process; there is no firing of neurons. VRG is involved in forceful expiration like during exercise.

The voluntary control of breathing is by the cerebral cortex through the cerebrospinal pathway. There is a reciprocal innervation to expiratory and inspiratory muscles, meaning that motor neurons supplying expiratory muscles are inactive when motor neurons supplying inspiratory muscles are active, and vice versa.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. In this case, the person breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval. This pattern repeats itself about every minute.

It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal individuals.

This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normally inhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relative hyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 rises again to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. Breathing ceases, and the cycle repeats.

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate is 98 beats/minute, no respirations are noted. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A term neonate who remains apnoeic despite stimulation should be given positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask. 
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV is provided with a bag and mask initially on room air and SPO2 monitoring is done. Increasing concentration of oxygen is used to ensure adequate ventilation.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

Self-inflating bag and mask, also known as AMBU bag - Artificial manual breathing unit.

questions.text: A patient has a ​blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 90 ml/min.
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml
                               = 180 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (transport maximum)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is of a secondary follicle, also called an antral follicle.

Development of ovarian follicles: 

At birth, the ovarian cortex contains numerous primordial follicles which contain primary oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flat follicular cells. Most of these follicles degenerate in the prepubertal life and are called atretic follicles. At puberty, around 20 primordial follicles get activated in each menstrual cycle. Out of these 20 primordial follicles, only one follicle is dominant which reaches maturity and releases the oocyte during ovulation. 

The different stages of development of the primordial follicle are: 

a) Primary follicle:

  • Follicle cells change from flattened cells to cuboidal and the stromal cells surrounding the follicle differentiate into spindle-shaped cells called 'theca externa'.
  • The oocyte increases in size and secretes a proteoglycan material around it which forms the layer called 'Zona Pellucida' which is seen between the plasma membrane of the oocyte and the granulosa cells. 

b)Secondary follicle(Antral follicle):

  • The primary follicles continue to increase in size and the granulosa cells multiply.
  • Numerous cavities coalesce to form a single fluid space called antrum.
  • The granulosa cells envelop the oocyte to form a structure called Cumulus oophorus.

c) Tertiary follicle (Graffian follicle):

  • Numerous secondary follicles are formed but only one tertiary follicle develops while others regress and become atretic follicles.
  • As the antrum draws the fhe follicle increase in size and expands to a diameter of 2 cm to become Graffian follicle.
  • The oocyte and the surrounding granulosa cells called corona radiata break away from the follicular wall and float in the follicular fluid.
  • The primary oocyte completes its first meiotic division to form the secondary oocyte and a polar body.
  • The secondary oocyte is arrested in the metaphase of the second meiotic division until fertilization takes place.
  • The follicle ruptures to release the oocyte which is captured by for the fimbriae.

d) Corpus Luteum:

  • The remainder of the follicle after ovulation is called the Corpus luteum. It synthesizes a carotenoid pigment called lutein which gives it a yellowish colour.
  • If the oocyte is not fertilized then corpus luteum degenerates 12-14 days after ovulation to become corpus albicans.
  • If fertilization occurs then the hCG produced by the trophoblast maintains the corpus luteum. It releases progesterone, estrogen, and relaxin, and regresses at around 8 weeks when the placenta takes over.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labelled 2?
questions.solution:
The plane marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The subcostal plane is an anatomical reference plane used in clinical and surgical practice. It is defined as a horizontal plane passing through the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage bilaterally. The 10th costal cartilage corresponds approximately to the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The costal cartilages are extensions of the ribs that articulate with the sternum anteriorly. The 10th costal cartilage is the cartilage of the 10th rib.

In the given image, structure 2 represents the subcostal plane, which corresponds to the level of the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage. Since the 10th costal cartilage is at the level of the upper border of L3, it indicates that the subcostal plane is also at the level of the upper border of L3.

    • L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). Corresponds to the origin of Inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (Paramedian or lateral planes)

  • Left hypochondriac, Epigastric, Right hypochondriac
  • Left lumbar, Umbilical (Central), Right lumbar
  • Left iliac, Hypogastric (Suprapubic), Right iliac

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • The supracristal plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.

  • Lumbar triangle (of Petit) is marked below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar herniation can occur here.

questions.text: Which of the following is a holocrine gland?
questions.solution:
Sebaceous gland is a holocrine type of gland.

The exocrine glands are classified into 3 types, depending on the mode of secretion:

  • Merocrine glands (eccrine or epicrine glands): the secretions are released out of the cell through a process called exocytosis with the cell remaining intact, e.g. eccrine sweat glands, salivary glands, exocrine pancreas, secretion of milk protein casein by mammary glands.
  • Apocrine glands: the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. e.g., sweat glands in axilla and anogenital regions and secretion of milk fat by mammary glands.
  • Holocrine glands: the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands.

questions.text:
During your visit to the CHC, you observe the ANM taking one frozen vaccine vial as a control and another vial of the same vaccine. She shakes both vials and attempts to compare the sedimentation rate of the solutes in them. For which of the following vaccines would you not conduct this test?

ANM- Auxiliary Nurse Midwife
questions.solution:
The shake test detects the freeze damage to vaccines. It is used for all freeze-sensitive vaccines - all the 'T-series' vaccines. The shake test is not used for the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine.

The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by the shake test.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.
  • Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. Examples: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Liquid Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), Hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A 1-day old boy is admitted to the neonatal ICU with cyanosis. This infant, who was born at term after an uncomplicated delivery, developed cyanosis after 2 hours. Pulse oximetry shows 80 % not improving with 100% O2. Records show continuous machinery murmur was heard at birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
questions.solution:
This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent congenital heart disease (CHD).

Cyanosis failing to improve with 100% oxygen(Option A) suggests an underlying cyanotic CHD.

Since the baby was asymptomatic at birth and developed cyanosis at 2 hrs of life, it coincides with the timing of the closure of PDA. The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, thereby preventing the onset of cyanosis.

Duct-dependent lesions: Anomalies, in a newborn with CHD, which are dependent on the patency of ductus arteriosus for survival.

  • Right-sided lesions (Tetralogy of Fallot, PA/PS) cannot pump blood to the lungs. These patients are dependent on an open PDA for pulmonary circulation.
  • Left-sided lesions (HLHS, AS, COA) cannot pump blood into the systemic circulation. These patients are dependent on open PDA for systemic circulation.

Indomethacin(Option B) causes the closure of PDA. This leads to loss of either pulmonary or systemic circulation, eventually causing death. Therefore, indomethacin is contraindicated in duct-dependent CHDs.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the fundoscopic image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. The intelligence of the child is normal.
