questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome is seen in hemochromatosis.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited genetic disorder. Mutation of the HFE gene leads to excessive absorption of iron which gets deposited in the liver, pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Histopathology shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes which stain positive with Prussian blue stain. Serum iron is raised and serum ferritin is significantly increased.

Hepatomegaly will be present in the majority of the patients with symptoms. Skin shows bronze pigmentation due to the increased deposition of iron and melanin over the dermis. Glucose levels are deranged or diabetes mellitus is seen due to the direct damage of the pancreatic islet cells by the deposition of iron.

Congestive cardiac failure is the most common cardiac manifestation of hemochromatosis. Features of cardiac failure will develop suddenly and rapidly progress, and if left untreated it may cause death. Hypogonadism due to failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis by deposition of iron. This may manifest as testicular atrophy or amenorrhea

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine, and oral deferasirox are effective. The main cause of death in hemochromatosis is cardiac failure. 

Other options:

Option B: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutation of this gene is associated with Cowden syndrome which leads to multiple cancers like breast cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer, and colorectal cancer.

Option C: ATP7B gene mutation causes Wilson's disease which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option D: MRP2 protein is associated with Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A neonate presents with facial dysmorphism as well as the characteristic findings shown in the image below. What is the chromosomal abnormality affecting this newborn?
questions.solution:
The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome. Edward's syndrome is caused due to trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 results in Edward’s syndrome, in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction. The clinical features include micrognathia, low-set ears, prominent occiput, and rocker bottom feet Prenatal ultrasound reveals fetal growth restriction.

The craniofacial features include dolichocephaly, short palpebral fissures, micrognathia, external anomalies of the ears, and redundant skin at the back of the neck.

Other features include a clenched fist with overriding fingers, i.e. index finger overlapping the third and 5th finger overlapping the 4th, small fingernails, underdeveloped thumbs, short sternum, and club feet.

Heart defects are the most common structural malformations seen in Edwards syndrome. It includes defects of septum, patent ductus arteriosus, valvular defects. 

Other options : 

Option A: Trisomy 13 is Patau Syndrome. It is characterised by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities. Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent. The midline facial abnormalities seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects associated with Patau’s syndrome include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows the facial abnormalities seen in Patau syndrome:

Option B: Trisomy 21 is Down syndrome. It is the most common chromosomal abnormality. Children with Down’s syndrome have severe mental retardation, which progressively declines with advancing age. Patients have characteristic facial features that include a flat facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and epicanthic folds. There is a horizontal palmar crease, and muscle tone at birth is decreased, which leads to a “floppy baby".

The image below is of a child with down syndrome.

Option D: Trisomy 11 is extremely rare and often leads to miscarriage in early pregnancy.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with dry, scaly dermatitis. On evaluation, he had a deficiency of essential fatty acids. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the essential fatty acid, linoleic acid, is likely to have caused this child's presentation of dry and scaly dermatitis.

Essential fatty acid (EFA) refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Clinical Significance of PUFA and EFA

  1. PUFAs are used for esterification and excretion of cholesterol.
  2. Deficiency of EFA causes acanthocytosis, hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia.
  3. EFA deficiency is connected with acrodermatitis enteropathica, hepatorenal syndrome, and CNS manifestations.
  4. Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger’s syndrome.
  5. DHA levels in the blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.
  6. Trans fatty acids will compete with EFAs and may increase the EFA deficiency and decrease the fluidity of membranes.

Other options:

Options A & B: Oleic and palmitoleic acids are non-essential fatty acids. They can be synthesized in the body naturally. 

Option D: Arachidonic acid is non-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesized from linoleic acid.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70 beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

  • Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL.
  • Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL.

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL.

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy with asthma is having frequent exacerbations despite being on high-dose ICS and LABA. His absolute eosinophil count is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate add-on drug?

ICS-inhaled corticosteroids

LABA: long-acting β-receptor agonists
questions.solution:
In patients on high-dose ICS and LABA with frequent acute exacerbations of asthma and elevated eosinophil count, the most appropriate add-on drug is Mepolizumab.

IL-5-blocking drugs are beneficial in patients with acute exacerbations of asthma and elevated eosinophil count. In this group, mepolizumab and reslizumab are monoclonal antibodies that bind to IL-5 and benralizumab binds to the IL-5 receptors.

Most patients with asthma have type 2 inflammation. TH2 type of helper T-cells are activated and they release IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. IL-4 induces B-cell isotype switching to cause the production of IgE. IgE binds to mast cells and causes sensitivity to environmental antigens. When an antigen comes in contact with the IgE antibody, the antigen-antibody reaction causes mast cell degranulation, resulting in bronchoconstriction and oedema. IL-5 is predominantly involved in the recruitment of eosinophils. IL-13 causes airway hyperresponsiveness and mucus hypersecretion. 

It has now been recognized that eosinophils play a major role in the pathophysiology of asthma. They induce airway hyperresponsiveness by releasing free radicals and major basic proteins, both of which can disrupt the airway epithelium. Mucus plugs, which contain significant amounts of eosinophil aggregates, accumulate in the airways and also contribute to the severity of asthma. By blocking IL-5, drugs like mepolizumab block the recruitment and functioning of eosinophils and bring about major symptomatic improvement in patients with asthma.

Other options:

Option A: Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is used as an add-on drug in COPD because bacterial infections are one of the most important causes of acute exacerbations in COPD.

Option B: Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase four inhibitor that is used in COPD as an add-on drug for reducing exacerbations. 

Option D: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. It is used in patients not adequately responding to high-dose ICS and LABA and with elevated circulating IgE and a positive skin test or radioallergosorbent test (RAST) to a perennial allergen.

questions.text: What is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle is the S phase.

The replication of the DNA genome occurs only at a specified time period during the cell cycle. This period is referred to as the synthetic or S phase. The S phase is separated from the mitotic, or M phase, by nonsynthetic periods referred to as gap 1 (G1) and gap 2 (G2) phases, occurring before and after the S phase, respectively. The cell prepares for DNA synthesis in G1, and for mitosis in G2.

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-M phase. Cells in the G2 or M phase do not have time to repair DNA damage that occurs before they start to divide. This affects mitosis, leading to catastrophe.

Cells become gradually less sensitive to radiation in the G1 phase to the early S phase and are least sensitive in the late S phase.

The most radiosensitive cell in the blood is the lymphocyte.

The least radiosensitive cell in the blood is the platelet.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition and was started on treatment. When can the child's treatment be considered complete?
  1. There is no edema for at least two weeks
  2. There is no edema for at least 4 weeks
  3. Weight for height reaches - 2 S.D or higher
  4. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm
  5. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 13.5 cm
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 4.

A child with severe acute malnutrition(SAM) may be considered to have completed treatment when there is no oedema for at least 2 weeks(Point 1), weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher(Point 3) and mid-upper-arm circumference is  >12.5 cm(Point 4).

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal oedema.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm.

Treatment: The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases, the initial stabilization phase focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions with 2-7 days of inpatient treatment. The rehabilitation phase focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues and it takes several weeks.

10 Steps: (mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients).

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed).
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover the head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal - Rehydration solution for malnutrition (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (4 mmol/kg/day) and magnesium (0.6 mmol/kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14 if there is the presence of xeropthalmia.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding.
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development.
    • Transfer to a home-based diet.

questions.text: Two days after penicillin administration, antibodies developed that resulted in hemolysis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. 

This is an example of drug-induced Type II hypersensitivity reaction.

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of eggs in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an oval egg with rhabditiform larvae indicate infection by Strongyloides stercoralis.

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

 Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Thin-walled
  • Transparent
  • Ovoid in shape
  • Contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

It is unique among human nematodes as it has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil. The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of Strongyloides is the filariform larva. When a person walks barefoot on soil containing the infective filariform larvae, they penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

Here, the larvae moult twice and become adult female worms. The eggs laid by the female in the intestinal mucosa hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

This autoinfection is not seen in Ancylostoma or Necator life cycle.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large intestinal worm, and its ova are typically seen in the stool, not larvae. It is not commonly associated with chronic diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised patients. 

Option B: Trichuris trichiura is also known as whipworm. The infective form is the embryonated egg that contains a rhabditiform larva. Patients are often asymptomatic except when the worm load is heavy where the disease manifests due to mechanical effects or allergic reactions. Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum with a mucus plug at both ends. Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. 

Option C: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the OPD with the following lesions shown in the image. It is present on the trunk and thighs but not on the palms and soles. Which of the following signs is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing reddish brown maculopapular lesions all over the body except palms and soles is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. Darier’s sign is positive in this condition.

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. It is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia in neonates.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in asymmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other options:

Option A: Headlight sign is the facial eczema sparing the periorbital, perinasal, and perioral areas. It is a feature of atopic dermatitis. Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous, pruritic patches or plaques, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy. Flexural surfaces are commonly involved in adults as seen in the image below.

Option B: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma and is caused due to the piloerection of the muscle.

Option C: Hertoghe's sign or Queen Anne's sign is defined as loss of lateral one-third of eyebrows (superciliary madarosis). It is seen in various conditions such as hypothyroidism, lepromatous leprosy, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, and alopecia areata.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is the Bainbridge reflex.

The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community?
questions.solution:
The spleen rate is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The spleen rate refers to the percentage of children aged 2 to 10 years showing an enlarged spleen. Surveys focusing on spleen enlargement exclude adults since various factors other than malaria can cause splenic enlargement in this population. The spleen rate is a commonly employed measure measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

Other options:

Option A: The slide positivity rate represents the proportion of slides that test positive for the presence of malarial parasites, regardless of the specific species. It provides information on the trend of malaria transmission.

Option C: The annual blood examination rate is the percentage of the number of slides examined in a population. It is an index of operational efficiency.

Option D: The annual parasitic incidence (API) is a method of assessing the incidence of malaria within a community. It involves comprehensive active and passive surveillance, with confirmed cases determined through blood examinations. In India, regions with an API≥2 per 1000 population per year are categorized as high-risk areas, making them eligible for targeted vector control measures.

Related Pearl: National Strategic Plan for Malaria Elimination 2017 - 2022

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly all the districts are classified into the following four categories

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in last three years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  District in which annual parasite incidence (API), is less than one per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between one and two per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts having API more than two.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goals of NSP strategy are phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1 - 2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at less than 1 by 2022

questions.text: Which of the following reactions in the diagram below would be hindered in a patient suffering from pellagra ?
questions.solution:
The above diagram is a representation of the different fates of the pyruvate complex.

Pellagra is a disease caused by niacin deficiency. Niacin is a constituent of NAD, NADP which is used as a cofactor for reactions involving dehydrogenase. A dehydrogenase is an enzyme that transfers a hydride from one molecule to another.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to Acetyl-CoA.

The three enzyme components are pyruvate dehydrogenase, dihydrolipoyl transacetylase, and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase. The Cofactors are thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), lipoic acid, coenzyme A, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+).

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2.

The above diagram is a representation of the different fates of the pyruvate complex. The given labellings are explained as follows.

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (B) needs thiamine pyrophosphate, lipoic acid, flavin, nicotinamide and Co-enzyme A. It is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (E) requires NADH.
  • Pyruvate kinase (A) which is an energy-producing reaction requires ADP.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase (C) requires biotin as Co-factor.
  • Pyruvate (D) is converted to alanine by alanine transaminase which requires pyridoxal phosphate.

questions.text: The drug that prevents hypercholesterolemia by directly inhibiting absorption of cholesterol is:

questions.text: Following delivery, a neonate is found to have delayed umbilical stump bleeding lasting for the last one month. Which among the following factor deficiencies is most likely in this child?
questions.solution:
Delayed umbilical stump bleeding is characteristic of factor XIII deficiency.

Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers and stabilises the fibrin clot, making it resistant to premature breakdown. Its deficiency leads to delayed wound healing, spontaneous bleeding, and in severe cases, life-threatening haemorrhages. It presents with recurrent umbilical bleeding since birth and epistaxis and rectal bleeding

Laboratory findings include normal PT, PTT, TT, platelet count and function. These indicate that the coagulation cascade and platelets are functioning normally up to fibrin formation. A positive urea clot solubility test is a classic diagnostic test for factor XIII deficiency. Clots deficient in Factor XIII dissolve in 5M urea because they lack cross-linked fibrin
The preferred treatment is FXIII concentrates. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and cryoprecipitate are alternatives. Antifibrinolytics like tranexamic acid can be adjunctive for minor bleeding. Regular monitoring and prophylaxis are crucial for long-term management and preventing complications.

Other options:

Option A: Factor VII deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder caused by insufficient or dysfunctional Factor VII, a key protein in the coagulation cascade. It leads to symptoms like prolonged bleeding, easy bruising, and excessive bleeding after injury or surgery.

Option B: Factor IX deficiency, also known as Hemophilia B or Christmas disease, is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder characterized by impaired blood clotting. It leads to prolonged bleeding, joint haemorrhages, and easy bruising due to reduced Factor IX activity in the coagulation cascade.

Option C: Factor XI deficiency typically causes mild to moderate bleeding, mainly in mucosal sites, and does not present with umbilical bleeding. PT and PTT may be prolonged, which is not the case here.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the clinical presentation of mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia is thymoma. 

Thymoma refers to the tumours of the thymic epithelial cells. They commonly occur in the anterior mediastinum. Clinical features can be chest pain, dyspnea, cough, or superior vena cava syndrome.

It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like myasthenia gravis, pure red cell aplasia, or hypogammaglobulinemia. It is rarely associated with limbic encephalitis, hemolytic anaemia, aplastic anaemia, and other autoimmune conditions like Sjogren's syndrome.

Pure red cell aplasia: It is a marrow disorder where only erythroid progenitors are suppressed. The complete absence of red cell progenitors is seen in severe cases.

Hereditary causes include Diamond-Blackfan anaemia or congenital pure red cell aplasia.

Acquired causes:

  • Cancer
    • Thymoma
    • Lymphoid malignancies (eg. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, large granular lymphocytosis)
    • Paraneoplastic to solid tumors
  • Connective tissue disorders with immunologic abnormalities
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Viruses
    • Persistent B19 parvovirus, hepatitis, adult T cell leukemia virus, Epstein-Barr virus
  • Drugs
    • Phenytoin, azathioprine, chloramphenicol, procainamide, isoniazid
  • Multiple endocrine gland insufficiency
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Idiopathic

Other options:

Option B: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can cause pure red cell aplasia but it commonly presents as peripheral adenopathy rather than mediastinal mass.

Options C and D: Germ cell tumors and bronchogenic carcinoma are not commonly known to be associated with red cell aplasia.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with complaints of weight loss, fatigue and poor appetite. Blood work and bone marrow examination revealed megaloblastic anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a purple polypoid mass lesion of 5mm diameter in the paracardiac region. Histopathologic examination of the gastric biopsy showed the deposition of amyloid materials in the mucosa. Which of the following stains is used to stain the amyloid material?
questions.solution:
The Congo red dye is used for staining amyloid bodies, which are abnormal, fibrous, extracellular proteinaceous deposits found in organs such as the liver, kidneys, and spleen. The dye forms nonpolar hydrogen bonds with amyloid.

The stain may be used on both gross specimens and microscopic sections; amyloid of all types stains pink red colour. If the stained section is viewed in polarised light, the amyloid characteristically shows apple-green birefringence due to cross β-pleated sheet configuration of amyloid fibrils.

Image: Histopathology of gastric amyloidosis. Deposition of amyloid seen on congo-red staining and apple-green birefringence in polarized light.

All the other three stains mentioned in the options are used to stain calcium.

Option B: Von Kossa method: It is a silver reduction method, where silver is substituted for calcium in calcium salts like calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate, leading to the formation of silver phosphate and silver carbonate, respectively. In the presence of light, the silver compounds undergo photochemical degeneration to silver, which turns to black colour. This method is useful when large amounts of phosphates and carbonates are present, as in the case of bone.

Option C: Alizarin red S: forms an orange-red lake with calcium at a pH of 4.2. It works best with small amounts of calcium such as in Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, which are pathognomonic feature of malakoplakia. This method is also used on DuPont Automatic Cyclical Analyser (ACA) to measure serum calcium photometrically.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these TWO variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed, but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This does not apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate way to discard an expired cytotoxic drug?
questions.solution:
Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs to be returned back to the manufacturer or supplier for incineration.

Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytoxic drugs need to be subjected to incineration or encapsulation or plasma pyrrolysis at a temperature of 1200 degree celcius.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator. Image of an incinerator is as shown below.

Other options : 

Option A : Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Option B : Disinfection with sodium hypochlorite is performed for broken or discarded glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, unless tainted with cytotoxic wastes.

Option C : Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. questions.text: A new drug is introduced into the market after which phase of the clinical trials?
questions.solution:

Phase III of the clinical trial checks the efficacy and monitors the adverse reactions of a new drug and thus a new drug is introduced after this phase.

Phase II takes place over a short duration. During this period, the most prominent side effects are assessed. However, less common side effects might have gone undetected due to the shorter duration and smaller study group.

Phase III takes place over a longer duration and includes more population as compared to Phase II. Because these studies are larger and longer in duration, the results are more likely to show long-term or rare adverse effects. Hence, this phase is used to monitor adverse effects.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Meissner’s plexus is present in submucosa
Myentric plexus is present between inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer
Muscularis mucosa is associated with peristalsis
Villi are absent in large intestine

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is that the muscularis mucosa is responsible for peristalsis, as it is actually the muscularis propria that is associated with peristalsis.

Contraction of muscularis mucosa alters absorptive and secretive surface area.

The enteric nervous system consists of two neuronal plexuses:  

  • Myenteric or Auerbach's plexus. 
  • Submucosal or Meissner's plexus.

The myenteric plexus (Auerbach’s plexus) is present between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layers(Option B). It controls gastrointestinal movements of peristalsis along the length of the gut. On stimulation, this plexus increases the tonicity, intensity, and rate of the intestinal contractions. It also increases the velocity of excitatory wave conduction along the gut. 

The myenteric plexus also has inhibitory effects through inhibitory transmitters like vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). These inhibitory signals control the progress of digested food along the GIT, like the pyloric sphincter and the ileocecal valve.

The submucosal plexus (Meissner’s plexus) is located in the submucosa (Option A) and is responsible for the function of the inner wall of the gut. It regulates local intestinal secretions, intestinal absorption, and the degree of folding of the mucosa (via the action of muscularis mucosae). Villi are absent in the large intestine, but present in the small intestine(Option D).

questions.text: A 30-year-old female has been fasting. Which of the following cycles provides a major source of glucose for the body from skeletal muscle breakdown in such conditions?
questions.solution:
In a fasting state, the Cahill cycle also known as glucose-alanine cycle provides the major source of glucose for the body from muscle breakdown of amino acids.

In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from muscle as it is the major substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Muscle glycogen cannot be utilized directly from the muscle as muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase essential for the breakdown of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose.

Other options :

Option A: The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle / glucose-lactate cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. 

Option C: Krebs cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D: Rapoport-lumbering cycle takes place in the red blood cells (RBC). Here 1, 3- Bisphosphoglycerate kinase is bypassed, no ATPs are produced in that step. Only 2 ATPs are generated by the pyruvate kinase step and 2 ATPs are utilized in the steps catalyzed by hexokinase and Phosphofructokinase - 1. So this pathway yields no net generation of ATP from glycolysis.

questions.text: An elderly man was caught peeping into a bathroom window and watching a girl disrobe. During his psychiatric evaluation, he confessed that he attains sexual gratification when he watches people naked or while they are engaged in any sexual activity without their knowledge. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Attaining sexual gratification after observing someone naked or engaged in sexual activity is called voyeurism. 

Voyeurism is also called scopophilia. It is more common in men. The voyeuristic act may be accompanied by masturbation. 

Paraphilias (perversions) are sexual stimuli or acts that are considered deviations from normal sexual behaviors. These are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Individuals with paraphilias do not experience sexual pleasure through stimuli that are considered normal.

Other options:

Option A: In transvestism there is a sexual urge to dress in opposite-gender clothing as a means of arousal. It is diagnosed when these fantasies have been acted upon for at least six months. 

Option B: Coprophilia is attaining sexual pleasure by defecating on the partner or by being defecated on. An urge to eat feces (coprophagia) may also be seen. 

Option D: Frotteurism is characterized by the rubbing of genitals against the buttocks or any other parts of the body of a woman who is fully clothed. This is done to achieve an orgasm and usually occurs in crowded places.

*Note: Exhibitionism is characterized by a recurrent urge to expose the genitals to strangers. The anticipation of the exposure results in sexual excitement and orgasm.

questions.text: A child who was stung multiple times after disturbing a bee hive developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse within minutes. Which of the following is the principal mediators of this reaction?
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity and the principal mediator involved here is histamine.

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies. It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. 

Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the FcεRI receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are:

  • Histamine
  • Proteases
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines.

The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis. It occurs in two phases: 

  • The immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with an abdominal wall mass, initially a bluish birthmark that gradually enlarged. The child appears developmentally normal. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a mass in the inguinal and hypogastric regions. The overlying skin is reddish-blue, smooth, and non-inflamed. No organomegaly is noted. A mild purpuric rash covers the body. Lab results show hemoglobin at 10.6 gm/dl and platelet count at 90,000/Cmm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an infant presenting with an abdominal wall mass, a distended abdomen with a mass in the inguinal and hypogastric regions and given physical examination and lab findings suggest a diagnosis of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (KMS), also known as Kasabach-Merritt phenomenon, is characterized by an enlarging vascular lesion, profound thrombocytopenia, consumptive coagulopathy, and often a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

KMS is associated with vascular tumors, especially kaposiform Hemangio Endothelioma(KHE) and Tufted Angioma(TA).

The syndrome results in a consumptive coagulopathy from platelet trapping and aggregation within a specific type of hemangioma.The hemangioma is often within the skin but can be present anywhere, including retroperitoneal organs, the mediastinum, the pelvis, visceral organs, or the mesentery.

Patients usually show severe thrombocytopenia, low fibrinogen levels, high fibrin degradation products including D-dimer (due to fibrinolysis), and microangiopathic anemia.

Treatment aims to involute the tumour to prevent significant morbidity or mortality, or in response to a life-threatening event. Surgical excision is curative but most lesions are not amenable to this option.Medical management includes 

  • High dose corticosteroids
  • Propanolol
  • Vincristine
  • Actinomycin
  • Interferon - alpha
  • Radiation

Other options:

Option A: Neuroblastoma- It is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla. They arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumors in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. It can be differentiated from KMS by the absence of thrombocytopenia and normal coagulative state. 

Option B: Pyoderma gangrenosum- Neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders.

Option C: Sweet's syndrome presents as an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis which is characterized by non‐itchy, sometimes tender, erythematous plaques and papules.

  • The plaques are often oedematous and as the process develops they may become studded with pseudovesicles or pseudopustules (no fluid collection present).
  • The lesions in Sweet's Syndrome are most commonly distributed on the arms, upper body, head and neck.
  • An associated fever and peripheral leucocytosis are commonly seen and females are more frequently affected.
  • Histological findings include a dense dermal neutrophilic infiltrate with oedema.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man came to the orthopedic outpatient clinic with a high stepping gait and is found to have a fracture at the neck of the fibula on an X-ray. This is associated with a loss of sensation in which of the following area/areas of the foot?
questions.solution:
A fracture at the neck of the fibula and a high stepping gait (foot drop) suggests injury to the common fibular nerve. This is associated with loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot (marked 4) and the first interdigital space (marked 1). 

The nerves supplying the marked areas are shown below.

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th and 5th lumbar and 1st and 2nd sacral ventral rami. It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. 

The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep fibular nerve while the dorsum of the foot (except lateral and medial borders) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve.

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

questions.text: As an intern in the community medicine department, you are asked to study the various graphical representations of data. What is the following graph best used for?

choices.text: Correlating risk factors of a disease
Studying the periodic trends of disease over time

questions.solution:
The graph depicted is a Kaplan-Meir plot and the use of the graph is survival time analysis.

Survival time analysis includes studying of -

  • What is the survival time of patients with a given disease.
  • How does this survival time compare between two groups of patients given different treatments for the same disease.
  • Among those who survive up to a certain time, at what time or rate can they be expected to die.
  • What factors, such as risk factors or treatments, affect the survival time.

Despite its name, survival analysis can be used to help answer questions of this kind about any kind of event, not just death—such as how long it takes before a hip replacement fails, how long it takes before a patient has a second heart attack, or how long it takes for coronary stents to become re-stenosed.

Other options -

Option A: The line of best fit is used to express a relationship in a scatter plot of different data points as a straight line rather than multiple dots. It is an output of regression analysis and can be used as a prediction tool.

Option C: Scatter diagrams are used to correlate risk factors of the disease and present as positive correlation, negative correlation or no correlation. 

Option D: A line diagram is used to study the periodic trends of a disease over time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient came to the hospital with rashes, arthralgia, myalgia, and photosensitivity for a week. She was diagnosed with tuberculosis and has been on anti-tubercular treatment for the past 3 months. She has no past history of similar episodes. Serum auto-antibody associated with her condition is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the patient's current symptoms is drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE).  Anti-histone antibody, an antibody against histone associated with DNA in chromatin, is seen particularly in cases of drug- induced lupus than SLE.

Isoniazid is one of the most common causes of DILE. The rash is spread over both cheeks, forming the typical malar rash. The patient also has other systemic symptoms including arthralgia and myalgia. The patient will be positive for anti-histone antibodies.

Drug-induced lupus usually occurs after 2-3 months of exposure to the offending drug and will spontaneously resolve on stopping the drug.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in which injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

An SLE like syndrome may develop in patients receiving variety of drugs, including 

  • Hydralazine
  • Procainamide
  • Isoniazid
  • Chlorpromazine
  • D- Penicillamine
  • Anti- TNF Therapy

Many of these drugs are associated with the development of ANAs, but most patients do not have symptoms of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are present in 75% of cases of DIL.

The mainstay of treatment is recognition and discontinuation of the offending drug. Development of positive ANA alone after receiving a drug shall not be a reason for discontinuation of the drug, although these patients shall be closely monitored for the development of DIL. Symptoms of DIL usually resolve within a few weeks of discontinuation of the medication, although rarely, they may last several months. NSAIDs or low dose corticosteroids may be considered for milder manifestations, with high dose corticosteroids reserved for more serious manifestations such as symptomatic pericardial effusion.

Option B: Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self IgG found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is also found in other collagen tissue disorders.

Option C: Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with the calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia (CREST) syndrome.

questions.text: A  patient with gout develops hypertension.  The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazides are not given to this patient.

Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

  • Dizziness

It is used in combination with a diuretic, in elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension. CNS side effects like depression and nightmares are seen. It does not precipitate gout.

Option C: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and its side effects include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness. It does not precipitate gout.

Option D: Prazosin is a selective α1 antagonist. It is generally not used as an initial agent to treat hypertension, except in symptomatic prostatism or nightmares linked to posttraumatic stress disorder. Headache is one of the side effects of prazosin.

questions.text: A young man presents with a painless mass in the submandibular region. On performing drainage, the discharge contained yellow granules and was foul-smelling. Microscopy of the sample showed gram-positive filamentous rods. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The patient presents with a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. Penicillin G is the drug of choice.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis: Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance). Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

Treatment involves surgical drainage or excision along with high doses of intravenous penicillin G over two to six weeks, followed by oral penicillin V.
